  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:

payload.text:
**Aligning auth and payload handling**

I'm planning to use HearthlinkClient.initialize for auth tokens and user IDs while keeping AuthenticatedRequest using only auth_token and a flattened payload. For process profiles, I'll implement required fields like description and created_at as per requirements, adding normalization to map backend data flexibly. The create/update payload will include required fields from the requirement plus default required_skills and version_pins to ensure backend compatibility.

**Designing UI with flexible profile handling**

I'm planning a badge component to show skill counts and a responsive UI with cards for the form and profile list, using CSS variables for theming. Profiles will normalize backend fields flexibly, supporting optimistic updates for create/update/delete with temp IDs and rollback on errors. Payloads will include both id and profile_id for safety, and skill inputs will parse flexible comma/newline formats.

I'm mapping out the component structure, import conventions, and state handling with form interfaces, skill parsing helpers, and loading logic, setting up for consistent UI using shared Card and Badge components. Next, I'll implement the full component code with these aligned imports and patterns.

**Designing process profile management logic**

+import * as React from "react"
+
+import { cn } from "@/lib/utils"
+
+export interface BadgeProps extends React.HTMLAttributes<HTMLSpanElement> {
+  variant?: "default" | "outline" | "muted" | "alert"
+}
+
+const Badge = React.forwardRef<HTMLSpanElement, BadgeProps>(
+  ({ className, variant = "default", ...props }, ref) => {
+    const variantClasses =
+      variant === "outline"
+        ? "border border-input text-foreground"
+        : variant === "muted"
+        ? "bg-muted text-muted-foreground"
+        : variant === "alert"
+        ? "bg-destructive/10 text-destructive border border-destructive/40"
+        : "bg-primary/10 text-primary border border-primary/40"
+
+    return (
+      <span
+        ref={ref}
+        className={cn(
+          "inline-flex items-center rounded-full px-2.5 py-0.5 text-xs font-semibold tracking-wide",
+          variantClasses,
+          className
+        )}
+        {...props}
+      />
+    )
+  }
+)
+Badge.displayName = "Badge"
+
+export { Badge }
*** End Patch

payload.message:
Built the Process Profile Manager UI with create/edit/delete flows, optimistic updates, and Tauri IPC calls, plus a lightweight Badge component to support the required skill tags. The UI follows MythTech styling via CSS variables and uses the shared `@/components/ui` primitives.

Details:
- New component at `src/components/core/ProcessProfileManager.tsx` with list + form layout, loading/error states, and invoke calls for list/create/update/delete.
- Added `Badge` to the shared UI library at `src/components/ui/badge.tsx` and exported it via `src/components/ui/index.ts`.

Next steps:
1) Verify the IPC command names/payloads for `core_update_process_profile` and `core_delete_process_profile`, since the backend currently only exposes create/get/list in `src-tauri/src/core/commands.rs`.
2) Add the new component to your Core dashboard or route if you want it visible in the app.

content.text:
Built the Process Profile Manager UI with create/edit/delete flows, optimistic updates, and Tauri IPC calls, plus a lightweight Badge component to support the required skill tags. The UI follows MythTech styling via CSS variables and uses the shared `@/components/ui` primitives.

Details:
- New component at `src/components/core/ProcessProfileManager.tsx` with list + form layout, loading/error states, and invoke calls for list/create/update/delete.
- Added `Badge` to the shared UI library at `src/components/ui/badge.tsx` and exported it via `src/components/ui/index.ts`.

Next steps:
1) Verify the IPC command names/payloads for `core_update_process_profile` and `core_delete_process_profile`, since the backend currently only exposes create/get/list in `src-tauri/src/core/commands.rs`.
2) Add the new component to your Core dashboard or route if you want it visible in the app.
